concept.title: Handling Problems in the Provisioning Process

section.p: If the provisioning of a virtual servera virtual systema VMresources fails on the AWSOpenStackvSphereAzure side or if there are problems in the communication between the participating systems, the corresponding subscription in remains pending. The AWSOpenStackVMwareAzure service controller informs the technology managers of its responsible technology provider organization by email of any incomplete provisioning or deleteprovisioning or delete operation in AWSOpenStackvSphereAzure.

You can then take the appropriate actions to solve the problem in AWSOpenStackvSphere or in the communication. For example, you could remove an incomplete virtual servervirtual systemVM, or you could restore a missing connection.

After solving the problem, the AWSOpenStackvSphereAzure integration components and need to be synchronized accordingly. You do this by triggering a corresponding action in the APP component. Proceed as follows:

ol.li: Work as a technology manager of the technology provider organization responsible for the AWSOpenStackVMwareAzure service controller.

Invoke the instance status interface of APP for the service controller of the application by opening it's URL in a Web browser.
The access URL has the following format:
https://<hostname.fqdn>:<port>/oscm-app/controller/?controllerid=ess.awsopenstackvmware
<hostname.fqdn> is the name and the fully qualified domain name of the machine where the oscm-app container has been deployed, <port> is the port to address the machine (default: 8881), oscm-app/controller/?controllerid=ess.awsopenstackvmwareazure is the default context root of the service controller and cannot be changed.
The Web page shows all subscriptions for the application, including detailed information such as the customer organization, the ID of the related application instance, and the provisioning status.
Find the subscription for which you solved the problem in the most recent provisioning or deleteprovisioning or deleteprovisioning, modification, or deleteprovisioning or delete operation.

In the Action column, select the action for the AWSOpenStackvSphereAzure integration components to execute next. Possible actions are the following:
RESUME - to resume the processing of a provisioning operation in APP which was suspended.
SUSPEND - to suspend the processing of a provisioning operation in APP, for example when AWSOpenStackvSphereAzure does not respond.
UNLOCK - to remove the lock for an AWSan OpenStacka VMAzure instance in APP.
DELETE - to terminate the subscription in and remove the instance in APP, but keep the virtual server in AWSvirtual system in OpenStackVM in vSphereresources in Azure for later use. The service manager role is required for this action.
DEPROVISION - to terminate the subscription in , remove the instance in APP, and delete the virtual server in AWSvirtual system in OpenStackVM in vSphereresources in Azure. The service manager role is required for this action.
ABORT_PENDING - to abort a pending provisioning operationprovisioning operationprovisioning or modification operationprovisioning operation in . is notified to roll back the changes made for the subscription and return it to its previous state. In AWSOpenStackvSphereAzure, no actions are carried out.
COMPLETE_PENDING - to complete a pending provisioning operationprovisioning operationprovisioning or modification operationprovisioning operation in . is notified to complete the changes for the subscription and set the subscription status to ready (or suspended if it was suspended before). This is possible only if the operations of the service controller are already completed.
Click Execute to invoke the selected action.

section.p: The instance status interface provides the following additional functionality that is useful for problem-solving purposes:

ul.li: You can display service instance details for each subscription by clicking the corresponding entry in the table. This displays all subscription-related information that is stored in the bssapp database.
